docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Install NoQL using the npm install command:

npm i @synatic/noql --save

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
NoQL's parseSQL method outputs an object with a type, either query or aggregate, along with the components of the Mongo query. To use the output object, construct a query with MongoClient from the MongoDB NodeJS Driver:

Example usage of parseSQL with MongoClient

Node.js:

const SQLParser = require('@synatic/noql');
const {MongoClient} = require('mongodb');

(async () => {
    try {
        client = new MongoClient('mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017');
        await client.connect();
        const db = client.db('noql-test');

        const parsedSQL = SQLParser.parseSQL(
            "select id from `films` limit 10", 
            { database: 'postgresql' /* or 'mysql' */ } });
        if (parsedSQL.type === 'query') {
            console.log(
                await db
                    .collection(parsedSQL.collection)
                    .find(parsedSQL.query || {}, parsedSQL.projection || {})
                    .limit(parsedSQL.limit || 50)
                    .toArray()
            );
        } else if (parsedSQL.type === 'aggregate') {
            console.log(
                await db
                    .collection(parsedSQL.collections[0])
                    .aggregate(parsedSQL.pipeline)
                    .toArray()
            );
        }
    } catch (exp) {
        console.error(exp);
    }
})();

See the API Reference for more information.

docs.title: parseSQL(sqlStatement, options)
docs.text:
Parses the given SQL statement to a JSON output object containing Mongo query components. It automatically determines if the output should be an aggregate pipeline or query depending on if a straight query is possible. The output JSON object properties can be used to construct a MongoDB query.

  • sqlStatement <string> - The SQL statement to parse
  • options <object> - Options for the parser
  • database <string> - The database type. Can be mysql or postgresql. Defaults to mysql.
  • Returns: <object>
  • type <string> - The type of query. Can be query or aggregate.
  • collection <string> - The collection to query for a query type.
  • query <object> - The query object to use for a query type.
  • projection <object> - The projection object to use for a query type.
  • limit <number> - The limit to use for a query type.
  • pipeline <array> - The aggregate array to use for an aggregate type.
  • collections <array> - The collections to use for an aggregate type.
Example parseSQL usage for a query

Node.js: 

const SQLMongoParser=require('@synatic/noql');

SQLMongoParser.parseSQL(
            "select id from `films` where `id` > 10 limit 10", 
            { database: 'postgresql' /* or 'mysql' */ } );

Output:

{
    "limit": 10,
    "collection": "films",
    "projection": {
        "id": "$id"
    },
    "query": {
        "id": {
            "$gt": 10
        }
    },
    "type": "query"
}
Example parseSQL usage for an aggregate

Node.js:

const SQLMongoParser=require('@synatic/noql');

SQLMongoParser.parseSQL(
        "select id from `films` where `id` > 10 group by id"),
        { database: 'postgresql' /* or 'mysql' */ });
Output:

{
    "pipeline": [
        {
            "$match": {
                "id": {
                    "$gt": 10
                }
            }
        },
        {
            "$group": {
                "_id": {
                    "id": "$id"
                }
            }
        },
        {
            "$project": {
                "id": "$_id.id",
                "_id": 0
            }
        }
    ],
    "collections": [
        "films"
    ]
}

docs.title: Using the output with MongoClient
docs.text:
To use the output object, construct a query with MongoClient from the MongoDB NodeJS Driver

Example usage with MongoClient

Node.js: 

const SQLParser = require('@synatic/noql');
const {MongoClient} = require('mongodb');

(async () => {
    try {
        client = new MongoClient('mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017');
        await client.connect();
        const db = client.db('noql-test');

        const parsedSQL = SQLParser.parseSQL(
                "select id from `films` limit 10",
                 { database: 'postgresql' /* or 'mysql' */ });
        if (parsedSQL.type === 'query') {
            console.log(
                await db
                    .collection(parsedSQL.collection)
                    .find(parsedSQL.query || {}, parsedSQL.projection || {})
                    .limit(parsedSQL.limit || 50)
                    .toArray()
            );
        } else if (parsedSQL.type === 'aggregate') {
            console.log(
                await db
                    .collection(parsedSQL.collections[0])
                    .aggregate(parsedSQL.pipeline)
                    .toArray()
            );
        }
    } catch (exp) {
        console.error(exp);
    }
})();

docs.title: parseSQLtoAST(sqlStatement, options)
docs.text:
Parses a SQL statement to an AST (abstract syntax tree)

  • sqlStatement <string> - The SQL statement to parse
  • options <object> - Options for the parser
  • database <string> - The database type. Can be mysql or postgresql. Defaults to mysql.
  • Returns: <object>
  • tableList <string[]> - A list of tables used in the query
  • columnList <string[]> - A list of columns used in the query
  • ast <object> - The AST (abstract syntax tree) of the query
Example parseSQLtoAST usage

Node.js 

const SQLMongoParser = require('@synatic/noql');

SQLMongoParser.parseSQLtoAST(
    "select id from `films`", 
    { database: 'postgresql' /* or 'mysql' */ });

Output: 

{
    "tableList": [
        "select::null::films"
    ],
    "columnList": [
        "select::null::id"
    ],
    "ast": {
        "with": null,
        "type": "select",
        "options": null,
        "distinct": null,
        "columns": [
            {
                "expr": {
                    "type": "column_ref",
                    "table": null,
                    "column": "id"
                },
                "as": null
            }
        ],
        "from": [
            {
                "db": null,
                "table": "films",
                "as": null
            }
        ],
        "where": null,
        "groupby": null,
        "having": null,
        "orderby": null,
        "limit": null,
        "for_update": null
    }
}

docs.title: makeMongoQuery(sqlStatement, options)
docs.text:
Generates Mongo query components from a SQL statement if possible. Throws an exception if not possible.

Use canQuery to test if a query can be created, or if an aggregate must be made instead.

If an aggregate must be made, use makeMongoAggregate instead. If you want NoQL to automatically choose, use parseSQL instead.

  • sqlStatement <string> - The SQL statement to parse
  • options <object> - Options for the parser
  • database <string> - The database type. Can be mysql or postgresql. Defaults to mysql.
  • Returns: <object>
  • type <string> - The type of query. It will be query.
  • collection <string> - The collection to query for a query type.
  • query <object> - The query object to use for a query type.
  • projection <object> - The projection object to use for a query type.
  • limit <number> - The limit to use for a query type.
Example makeMongoQuery usage

Node.js 

const SQLMongoParser=require('@synatic/noql');

SQLMongoParser.makeMongoQuery(
    "select id from `films` where id > 10 limit 10", 
    { database: 'postgresql' /* or 'mysql' */ });

Output: 

{
    "type": "query",
    "limit": 10,
    "collection": "films",
    "projection": {
        "id": "$id"
    },
    "query": {
        "id": {
            "$gt": 10
        }
    }
}

docs.title: makeMongoAggregate(sqlStatement, options)
docs.text:
Generates a mongo aggregate pipeline components from a SQL statement.

If your SQL statement can be represented by a straight query, use makeMongoQuery instead. If you want NoQL to automatically choose, use parseSQL instead.

  • sqlStatement <string> - The SQL statement to parse
  • options <object> - Options for the parser
  • database <string> - The database type. Can be mysql or postgresql. Defaults to mysql.
  • Returns: <object>
  • type <string> - The type of query. It will be aggregate.
  • pipeline <array> - The aggregate pipeline array to use for an aggregate type.
  • collections <array> - The collections to use for an aggregate type.
Example makeMongoAggregate usage

Node.js

const SQLMongoParser = require('@synatic/noql');

SQLMongoParser.makeMongoAggregate(
    "select id from `films` group by id", 
    { database: 'postgresql' /* or 'mysql' */ });
Output:

{
    "pipeline": [
        {
            "$group": {
                "_id": {
                    "id": "$id"
                }
            }
        },
        {
            "$project": {
                "id": "$_id.id",
                "_id": 0
            }
        }
    ],
    "collections": [
        "films"
    ]
}

docs.title: canQuery(sqlStatement, options)
docs.text:
Checks if a SQL statement can be represented by a straight Mongo query, or if an aggregate query must be used.

  • sqlStatement <string> - The SQL statement to check
  • options <object> - Options for the parser
  • database <string> - The database type. Can be mysql or postgresql. Defaults to mysql.
  • Returns: <boolean>
Example canQuery usage

Node.js:

const SQLMongoParser = require('@synatic/noql');

SQLMongoParser.canQuery('select id from `films`');
// Returns true

SQLMongoParser.canQuery('select id from `films` group by id');
//Returns false

docs.title: Aggregates
docs.text:
NoQL supports standard SQL aggregate functions with GROUP BY like SUM,AVG,MAX and MIN.

Aggregate results are returned as arrays for FIRSTN and LASTN.

docs.title: SUM
docs.text:
SUM(field)

Returns the sum of all values in the given field.

Example SUM usage 
SELECT 
    SUM(`id`) AS aggrVal
    ,`Address.City` AS City 
FROM 
    `customers` 
GROUP BY 
    `Address.City` 
ORDER BY `Address.City`;

docs.title: AVG
docs.text:
AVG(field)

Returns the average of all values in the given field.

Example AVG usage 
SELECT
    AVG(`id`) AS aggrVal
    ,`Address.City` AS City
FROM
    `customers`
GROUP BY 
    `Address.City`
ORDER BY 
    `Address.City`;

docs.title: MIN
docs.text:
MIN(field)

Returns the minimum value in the given field.

Example MIN usage 
SELECT
    MIN(`id`) AS aggrVal
    ,`Address.City` AS City
FROM 
    `customers`
GROUP BY
    `Address.City`
ORDER BY
    `Address.City`;

docs.title: MAX
docs.text:
MAX(field)

Returns the maximum value in the given field.

Example MAX usage 
SELECT 
    MAX(`id`) AS aggrVal
    ,`Address.City` AS City
FROM
    `customers`
GROUP BY
    `Address.City`
ORDER BY
    `Address.City`;

docs.title: COUNT
docs.text:
COUNT(field)

Returns the count of rows in the given group.

Example COUNT usage 
SELECT 
    COUNT(*) AS countVal
    ,`Address.City` AS City
FROM
    `customers`
GROUP BY
    `Address.City`
ORDER BY
    `Address.City`;

docs.title: COUNT DISTINCT
docs.text:
COUNT(DISTINCT field)

Returns the distinct count of a specific field in the given group.

Example COUNT DISTINCT usage 
SELECT 
    COUNT(DISTINCT "Address.Town") AS countVal
    ,`Address.City` AS City
FROM
    `customers`
GROUP BY
    `Address.City`
ORDER BY
    `Address.City`;

docs.title: FIRSTN
docs.text:
FIRSTN(limit)

Returns the first n records in the group as an array

Example FIRSTN usage 
SELECT
    `Address.City` AS City
    ,FIRSTN(10) as CustomersPerCity
FROM 
    `customers`
GROUP BY
    `Address.City`;

docs.title: LASTN
docs.text:
LASTN(limit)

Returns the last n records in the group as an array

Example LASTN usage 
SELECT
    `Address.City` AS City
    ,LASTN(10) as CustomersPerCity
FROM 
    `customers`
GROUP BY
    `Address.City`;

docs.title: SUM - CASE Logic
docs.text:
Sum Case logic is supported:

Example SUM - CASE usage 
SELECT 
    SUM(CASE WHEN `Address.City`='Ueda' THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) AS Ueda
    ,SUM(CASE WHEN `Address.City`='Tete' THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) AS Tete 
FROM 
    `customers`

docs.title: Array Support
docs.text:
NoQL supports many methods that perform operations on array fields. They can be used as part of select statements and queries.

NoQL uses sub-selects with a FROM array field to query array fields in collections. E.g.

Using sub-selects to query array fields 
SELECT
    (SELECT * FROM Rentals WHERE staffId=2) AS t
FROM
    `customers`

Using '$$ROOT' in sub select promotes the field to the root value of the array

Using '$$ROOT' in sub select 
SELECT
    (SELECT filmId AS `$$ROOT` FROM Rentals WHERE staffId=2) AS t
FROM
    `customers`

Slicing the array is supported by limit and offset in queries

Slicing an array with limit and offset 
SELECT
    (SELECT * FROM Rentals WHERE staffId=2 LIMIT 10 OFFSET 5) AS t
FROM
    `customers`

Sorting Arrays is supported in MongoDB 5.2+ and NoQL

Sorting Arrays is supported 
SELECT id,
    (SELECT * FROM Rentals ORDER BY id DESC) AS totalRentals
FROM customers

Aggregation functions are not supported in a sub select

Aggregation functions are not supported in a sub select. For example, the following won't work sql --Wont'Work SELECT id, (SELECT count(*) AS count FROM Rentals) AS totalRentals FROM customers

docs.title: UNWIND Function
docs.text:
UNWIND(array_expr)

NoQL has a high level unwind function that will unwind array fields. For Joins, the unwind join hint should be used.

UNWIND in SELECT 
SELECT
  field1,
  UNWIND(arrFld) as arrFld
FROM
  test
Complex UNWIND 
SELECT
    MERGE_OBJECTS(
        (SELECT
            t.CustomerID
            ,t.Name
        )
        ,t.Rental
        ) AS `$$ROOT`
FROM
    (SELECT
        id AS CustomerID
        ,`First Name` AS Name
        ,UNWIND(Rentals) AS Rental
    FROM customers) AS t

docs.title: ALL_ELEMENTS_TRUE
docs.text:
ALL_ELEMENTS_TRUE(array expr)

Returns true when all elements in the array are true.

Example ALL_ELEMENTS_TRUE usage 
SELECT id,
    (CASE WHEN ALL_ELEMENTS_TRUE(Rentals) THEN 'Yes' ELSE 'No' END) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: JOIN
docs.text:
JOIN(array expr, delimiter)

Joins all values into a string.

Example JOIN usage 
SELECT id,
    JOIN((SELECT Name FROM Rentals),',') AS RentalNames
FROM customers;

docs.title: ANY_ELEMENT_TRUE
docs.text:
ANY_ELEMENT_TRUE(array expr)

Returns true when any element in the array is true.

Example ANY_ELEMENT_TRUE usage 
SELECT id,
    (CASE WHEN ANY_ELEMENT_TRUE(Rentals) THEN 'Yes' ELSE 'No' END) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: ARRAY_ELEM_AT
docs.text:
ARRAY_ELEM_AT(array expr,position)

Returns the element of an array at a position.

Example ARRAY_ELEM_AT usage 
SELECT id,
    ARRAY_ELEM_AT(Rentals,5) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: ARRAY_RANGE
docs.text:
ARRAY_RANGE(start,stop,step)

Generates an array of numbers from to with the specified step.

Example ARRAY_RANGE usage 
SELECT id,
    ARRAY_RANGE(0,10,2) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: ARRAY_TO_OBJECT
docs.text:
ARRAY_TO_OBJECT(array expr)

Converts the array to an object.

Example ARRAY_TO_OBJECT usage 
SELECT id,
    ARRAY_TO_OBJECT(OBJECT_TO_ARRAY(`Address`)) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: CONCAT_ARRAYS
docs.text:
CONCAT_ARRAYS(array expr,...)

Concatenate the provided list of arrays.

Example CONCAT_ARRAYS usage 
SELECT id,
    CONCAT_ARRAYS((SELECT `Film Title` AS `$$ROOT` FROM `Rentals`), ARRAY_RANGE(0,10,2)) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: FIRST_IN_ARRAY
docs.text:
FIRST_IN_ARRAY(array expr)

Returns the first element of an array.

Example FIRST_IN_ARRAY usage 
SELECT id,
    FIRST_IN_ARRAY(`Rentals`) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: INDEXOF_ARRAY
docs.text:
INDEXOF_ARRAY(array expr,value,[start],[end])

Returns the index of the value in the array.

Example INDEXOF_ARRAY usage 
SELECT id,
    INDEXOF_ARRAY((SELECT `Film Title` AS `$$ROOT` FROM `Rentals`),5) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: IS_ARRAY
docs.text:
IS_ARRAY(array expr)

Returns true when the field is an array.

Example IS_ARRAY usage 
SELECT id,
    (CASE WHEN IS_ARRAY(Rentals) THEN 'Yes' ELSE 'No' END) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: LAST_IN_ARRAY
docs.text:
LAST_IN_ARRAY(array expr)

Returns the last element of an array.

Example LAST_IN_ARRAY usage 
SELECT id,
    LAST_IN_ARRAY(`Rentals`) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: OBJECT_TO_ARRAY
docs.text:
OBJECT_TO_ARRAY(expr)

Converts the object to an array.

Example OBJECT_TO_ARRAY usage 
SELECT id,
    OBJECT_TO_ARRAY(`Address`) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: REVERSE_ARRAY
docs.text:
REVERSE_ARRAY(array expr)

Reverses the order of an array field.

Example REVERSE_ARRAY usage 
SELECT id,
    REVERSE_ARRAY(`Rentals`) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: SET_DIFFERENCE
docs.text:
SET_DIFFERENCE(array expr,...)

Returns an array as the difference of the provided arrays.

Example SET_DIFFERENCE usage 
SELECT id,
    SET_DIFFERENCE((SELECT `Film Title` AS `$$ROOT` FROM `Rentals`), PARSE_JSON('[ 1,2,3,4]')) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: SET_EQUALS
docs.text:
SET_EQUALS(array expr,...)

Returns true or false if the arrays are equal.

Example SET_EQUALS usage 
SELECT id,
    SET_EQUALS((SELECT `Film Title` AS `$$ROOT` FROM `Rentals`), PARSE_JSON('[ 1,2,3,4]')) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: SET_INTERSECTION
docs.text:
SET_INTERSECTION(array expr,...)

Returns an array as the difference of the provided arrays.

Example SET_INTERSECTION usage 
SELECT id,
    SET_INTERSECTION((SELECT filmId AS `$$ROOT` FROM `Rentals`), PARSE_JSON('[ 1,2,3,4]')) AS
test FROM `customers`;

docs.title: SET_IS_SUBSET
docs.text:
SET_IS_SUBSET(array expr,...)

Returns whether an array is a subset of another.

Example SET_IS_SUBSET usage 
SELECT id,
    SET_IS_SUBSET((SELECT filmId AS `$$ROOT` FROM `Rentals`), PARSE_JSON(‘[ 1,2,3,4] ‘)) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: SET_UNION
docs.text:
SET_UNION(array expr,...)

Returns an array as the union of the provided arrays.

Example SET_UNION usage 
SELECT id,
    SET_UNION((SELECT filmId AS `$$ROOT` FROM `Rentals`), PARSE_JSON(‘[ 1,2,3,4] ‘)) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: SIZE_OF_ARRAY
docs.text:
SIZE_OF_ARRAY(array expr)

Returns the size of array.

Example SIZE_OF_ARRAY usage 
SELECT id,
    SIZE_OF_ARRAY(`Rentals`) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: SUM_ARRAY
docs.text:
SUM_ARRAY(array expr,[field])

Sums the values in an array given an array field or sub-select and the field to sum.

Example SUM_ARRAY usage 
SELECT
    SUM_ARRAY(`Rentals`, 'staffId') AS totalStaffIds
FROM `customers`;
Example SUM_ARRAY usage with a sub select 
SELECT id,
    `First Name`,
    `Last Name`,
    SUM_ARRAY(
        (SELECT
            SUM_ARRAY(`Payments`, ‘Amount’) AS total
        FROM `Rentals`), ‘total’) AS t
FROM customers;

docs.title: AVG_ARRAY
docs.text:
AVG_ARRAY(array expr,[field])

Averages the values in an array given an array field or sub-select and the field to average.

Example AVG_ARRAY usage 
SELECT
    AVG_ARRAY(`Rentals`, 'staffId') AS avgStaffIds
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: ZIP_ARRAY
docs.text:
ZIP_ARRAY(array expr,...)

Transposes an array of input arrays so that the first element of the output array would be an array containing, the first element of the first input array, the first element of the second input array, etc.

Example ZIP_ARRAY usage 
SELECT id,
    ZIP_ARRAY(
        (SELECT `Film Title` AS `$$ROOT` FROM `Rentals`),ARRAY_RANGE(0,10,2)) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: Comparison Operators
docs.text: M-SQL Operator Description Example > Greater than select * from `films` where id > 10select (id>10) as exprVal from `films` < Less than select * from `films` where id < 10select (id<10) as exprVal from `films` = Equal to select * from `films` where id = 10 select (id=10) as exprVal from `films` >= Greater than or equal to select * from `films` where id >= 10select (id>=10) as exprVal from `films` <= Less than or equal to select * from `films` where id <= 10select (id<=10) as exprVal from `films` != Not equal to select * from `films` where id != 10 select (id!=10) as exprVal from `films` IS NOT NULL Is not null select * from `films` where id IS NOT NULL IS NULL Is null select * from `films` where id IS NULL LIKE String like, support standard %, case insensitive select `First Name` as FName from `customers` where `First Name` Like 'M%' GT Greater than select GT(id,10) as exprVal from `films` LT Less than select LT(id,10) as exprVal from `films` EQ Equal to select EQ(id,10) as exprVal from `films` GTE Greater than or equal to select GTE(id,10) as exprVal from `films` LTE Less than or equal to select LTE(id,10) as exprVal from `films` NE Not equal to select NE(id,10) as exprVal from `films` IN In a list of values select * from `customers` where `Address.City` in ('Japan','Pakistan') NOT IN Not in a list of values select * from `customers` where `Address.City` NOT IN ('Japan','Pakistan') CASE Case statement select id,(case when id=3 then '1' when id=2 then '1' else 0 end) as test from customers

docs.title: Conversion Functions
docs.text:
Tip

Literal types in WHERE clauses using conversion functions are converted automatically e.g.:

SELECT 
    TO_DATE(date) AS d 
    FROM customers 
WHERE 
    TO_DATE(date) > TO_DATE('2012-01-01')

NoQL will automatically convert the date value and result in the following:

{"$expr":{"$gt":[{"$toDate":"$date"},new Date("2012-01-01T00:00:00.000Z")]}}

docs.title: CONVERT
docs.text:
CONVERT(expr,to)

Converts the expression to the specified mongo type: double, string, bool, date, int, objectId, long, decimals.

Example CONVERT usage 
SELECT 
    SUBTRACT(CONVERT(‘1’,‘int’),ABS(`Replacement Cost`)) AS d,Title 
FROM 
    `films`

docs.title: IFNULL
docs.text:
IFNULL(expr,expr)

Return the value if the expression is null.

Example IFNULL usage 
SELECT 
    IFNULL(id,1) AS `conv` 
FROM 
    `customers`
Example using select without FROM clause for object generation 
SELECT 
    IFNULL(NULL,(select ‘a’ as val,1 as num)) AS `conv` 
FROM 
    `customers`

docs.title: TO_BOOL
docs.text:
TO_BOOL(expr)

Convert the expression to a boolean.

Example TO_BOOL usage 
SELECT 
    TO_BOOL(‘true’) AS `conv` 
FROM 
    `customers`

docs.title: TO_DATE
docs.text:
TO_DATE(expr)

Convert the expression to a date.

Example TO_DATE usage 
SELECT 
    TO_DATE(‘2021-12-15T00:00:00Z’) AS `conv` 
FROM 
    `customers`

docs.title: TO_DECIMAL
docs.text:
TO_DECIMAL(expr)

Convert the expression to a decimal.

Example TO_DECIMAL usage 
SELECT 
    TO_DECIMAL(‘123.35’) AS `conv` 
FROM 
    `customers`

docs.title: TO_DOUBLE
docs.text:
TO_DOUBLE(expr)

Convert the expression to a double.

Example TO_DOUBLE usage 
SELECT
     TO_DOUBLE(‘123.35’) AS `conv` 
FROM 
    `customers`

docs.title: TO_INT
docs.text:
TO_INT(expr)

Convert the expression to an integer.

Example TO_INT usage 
SELECT

docs.title: DATE_ADD
docs.text:
DATE_ADD(date, unit, amount, [timezone])

Adds a specified time interval to a date.

Example DATE_ADD usage 
SELECT
    id,
    item,
    orderDate as od1,
    DATE_ADD(orderDate, 'hour', 2) as od2
FROM orders
WHERE id = 2

You can also use the alias DATEADD:

docs.title: DATE_SUBTRACT
docs.text:

Subtracts a specified time interval from a date.

Example DATE_SUBTRACT usage

    id,

FROM orders

docs.title: DATE_DIFF
docs.text:
DATE_DIFF(startDate, endDate, unit, [timezone], [startOfWeek])

Calculates the difference between two dates in the specified unit.

Example DATE_DIFF usage 
SELECT
    id,
    item,
    orderDate,
    CURRENT_DATE() as now,
    DATE_DIFF(orderDate, DATE_ADD(orderDate, 'day', 2), 'day') as diff
FROM orders
WHERE id = 2
LIMIT 1

You can also use the alias DATEDIFF:

docs.title: DATE_TRUNC
docs.text:
DATE_TRUNC(date, unit)

Truncates a date to the specified unit of granularity.

Example DATE_TRUNC usage 
SELECT
    orderDate,
    DATE_TRUNC(orderDate, 'month') as monthStart,
    DATE_TRUNC(orderDate, 'year') as yearStart
FROM orders
LIMIT 5

The unit parameter can be one of the following:

  • 'year'
  • 'quarter'
  • 'month'
  • 'week'
  • 'day'
  • 'hour'
  • 'minute'
  • 'second'
  • 'millisecond'

This function is useful for grouping dates by a specific time unit or for finding the start of a time period.

Example DATE_TRUNC usage in grouping 
SELECT
    DATE_TRUNC(orderDate, 'month') as monthStart,
    COUNT(*) as orderCount
FROM orders
GROUP BY DATE_TRUNC(orderDate, 'month')
ORDER BY monthStart

This query groups orders by month and counts the number of orders in each month.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
NoQL aims to combine the ease of use and wide understanding of SQL Syntax with the power and flexibility of the MongoDB document model and aggregation pipeline.

To achieve this, NoQL is a SQL to MongoDB interpreter that provides for standard SQL statements with some caveats.

docs.title: Key Concepts
docs.text:
NoQL supports parsing of either MySQL or PostgreSQL syntax.

NoQL follows the MongoDB requirements for fields and values including:

  • Case-sensitive field names
  • Case-sensitive and type exact field values
  • Fields name cannot contain . or start with $

docs.title: Documents
docs.text:
NoQL supports the standard MongoDB query and aggregation notation for document navigation including:

  • Dot notation for field traversal including arrays
  • Operators for object and array field manipulation

docs.title: Objects
docs.text: NoQL provides a shortcut syntax to selecting fields from objects using a sub-select without a where clause. See Objects

docs.title: Arrays
docs.text: NoQL provides many methods for using arrays and functions by using a sub select with a where statement. See Arrays

docs.title: Joins
docs.text: NoQL currently supports complex inner and left outer joins with hints to simplify required output processing. See Joins

docs.title: Aliasing
docs.text:
NoQL requires aliasing (AS) for functions and sub queries

Example AS usage 
SELECT 
    ABS(-1) AS `absId` 
FROM 
    `customers`

Using AS on a table requires prefixing

Example AS usage with a table with prefixing 
SELECT 
    c.* 
FROM 
    customers AS c

Always alias on JOIN statements

docs.title: Indexing
docs.text: Complex aggregation pipelines on large sets of data requires an understanding of how MongoDB is utilising indexes, especially on joins. We are working on an index suggestion tool to simplify this process.

docs.title: Joins
docs.text: NoQL supports INNER and OUTER Joins, but does not unwind by default and the items are added as an array field.

docs.title: Join Hints
docs.text:
There are several join hints to simplify document model joining:

  • first
  • last
  • unwind
  • optimize

Join hints are added using a pipe | character to the join table or alias.

Example join hint 
--return the first item in the array
SELECT
     * 
FROM 
    orders 
INNER JOIN 
    `inventory` AS `inventory_docs|first` 
ON sku=item

docs.title: first
docs.text:
Returns the first element of the join result as an object on the result

Example first join hint 
--return the first item in the array
SELECT
     * 
FROM 
    orders 
INNER JOIN 
    `inventory` AS `inventory_docs|first` ON sku=item

docs.title: last
docs.text:
Returns the last element of the join result as an object on the result

Example last join hint 
--take the last item of the array
SELECT
     * 
FROM 
    orders 
INNER JOIN 
    `inventory` AS `inventory_docs|last` ON sku=item

docs.title: unwind
docs.text:
Unwinds the result into multiple records following the result of the join

Example unwind join hint 
--unwind the array to multiple documents
SELECT 
    * 
FROM 
    orders 
INNER JOIN 
    `inventory` AS `inventory_docs|unwind` ON sku=item

docs.title: optimize
docs.text:
The optimize hint is a current workaround to limit the result set for the $lookup when working with sub selects.

The $match on sub query joins is applied after the subquery pipeline which can cause performance issues since indexes may not be used. It may be better to put the match before the pipeline to limit the input set depending on the on conditions.

Example optimize usage 
SELECT 
    c.*
    ,cn.* 
FROM 
    customers c 
INNER JOIN
    (SELECT * FROM `customer-notes` WHERE id>2) `cn|optimize` 
ON 
    cn.id=c.id

The on field must be part of the sub query select to be a valid optimization.

docs.title: JOIN Array Functions
docs.text:
Alternatively the explicit array functions FIRST_IN_ARRAY, LAST_IN_ARRAY, UNWIND can be used instead of the join hints:

Example FIRST_IN_ARRAY usage 
--return the first item in the array
SELECT 
    *
    ,FIRST_IN_ARRAY(inventory) AS inventory_docs 
FROM 
    orders 
INNER JOIN `inventory` ON sku=item
Example LAST_IN_ARRAY usage 
--take the last item of the array
SELECT *
    ,LAST_IN_ARRAY(inventory) AS inventory_docs 
FROM orders 
INNER JOIN 
    `inventory` ON sku=item
Example UNWIND usage 
--unwind the array to multiple documents
SELECT 
    *
    ,UNWIND(inventory) AS inventory_docs 
FROM
    orders
INNER JOIN 
    `inventory` ON sku=item

docs.title: Caveats
docs.text:
An IN sub-select on a WHERE clause does not work as a join. Use a join instead.

Example IN sub-select. This won't work. 
    --Won't Work
    SELECT 
        *, inventory_docs
    FROM 
        orders
    WHERE 
        inventory_docs IN 
        (SELECT 
            * FROM inventory
        WHERE 
            sku= orders.item
        )
Using JOIN instead of IN sub-select 
--use join instead
SELECT
     *
FROM
     orders
INNER JOIN
    inventory inventory_docs ON sku=item

docs.title: Limit and Offset
docs.text:
NoQL supports MySQL and PostgresQL style limits and offsets that equates to limit and skip in MongoDB. For example:

Using LIMIT and OFFSET 
SELECT 
    (SELECT * FROM Rentals) AS t 
FROM 
    `customers` 
LIMIT 10 OFFSET 2

docs.title: Mathematical Operators
docs.text: M-SQL Operator Description + Addition operator adds 2 numbers or dates. Does not work on strings select `Replacement Cost` + id + Length as exprVal from `films` - Subtraction operator subtracts 2 numbers or dates. Does not work on strings select `Replacement Cost` - id - Length as exprVal from `films` / Division operator divides 2 numbers or dates. Does not work on strings select `Replacement Cost` / id as exprVal from `films` * Multiplication operator multiplies 2 numbers or dates. Does not work on strings select `Replacement Cost` *id* Length as exprVal from `films` % Modulus operator select `id` % Length as exprVal from `films`

docs.title: $$ROOT
docs.text:
Specifying $$ROOT as a column alias sets the value to root object but only works with aggregates (unless contained in array sub select). This is useful when you want to return the root object as a column.

Example $$ROOT usage 
SELECT
    t AS `$$ROOT`
FROM
    (
    SELECT
        id
        ,`First Name`
        ,`Last Name`
        ,LENGTHOFARRAY(Rentals,'id')  AS numRentals
    FROM customers)
AS t

docs.title: Merge Fields into Object
docs.text:
Only available in aggregates. Use a SELECT without specifying a table to create a new object.

Creating a new object 
SELECT
    (SELECT id,`First Name` AS Name) AS t
FROM
    customers

Create a new Object and assign to root

Creating a new object and assigning to root 
SELECT
    (SELECT id,`First Name` AS Name) AS t1
    ,(SELECT id,`Last Name` AS LastName) AS t2
    ,MERGE_OBJECTS(t1,t2) AS `$$ROOT`
FROM
    customers

docs.text:

    ARRAY_TO_OBJECT(PARSE_JSON('[{"k":"val","v":1}]')) AS test
FROM `customers`;

docs.text:

SELECT

FROM `customers`;
Example MERGE_OBJECTS usage with sub select 
SELECT
    id,
    MERGE_OBJECTS(`Address`,(SELECT 1 AS val)) AS test
FROM `customers`;

FROM `customers`;
Example EMPTY_OBJECT usage in a condition 
SELECT
    id,
    `Address`,
    CASE
        WHEN `Address` = EMPTY_OBJECT() THEN 'No Address'
        ELSE 'Has Address'
    END AS addressStatus
FROM `customers`;

docs.text:
FLATTEN(field, prefix)

Flattens an object into a set of fields. You can optionally add a

Example FLATTEN usage

``sql' SELECT id, FLATTEN(address,'addr_') FROMcustomers`; 

???+ example "Example `FLATTEN` usage with unset"

```sql'
   SELECT
       id,
       FLATTEN(`address`,'addr_',true)
   FROM `customers`;

Will remove the address field from the output and will only have the addr_ prefixed fields.

SELECT 
    `Address.City` AS City, ABS(`id`) AS absId 
FROM 
    `customers` 
WHERE 
    `First Name` LIKE 'm%' AND ABS(`id`) > 1 
ORDER BY absId
Incorrect 
SELECT 
    `Address.City` AS City 
FROM 
    `customers` 
WHERE 
    `First Name` LIKE 'm%' AND ABS(`id`) > 1 
ORDER BY ABS(`id`)

docs.title: PIVOT
docs.text:
The PIVOT operation allows you to transform rows into columns, creating a cross-tabular format. In NoQL, the PIVOT operation is specified as a hint on the subquery.

Example PIVOT usage 
SELECT 'AverageCost' as CostSortedByProductionDays,
        "0",
        "1",
        "2",
        "3",
        "4"
FROM (
    SELECT DaysToManufacture,
           StandardCost
    FROM Production_Product
    GROUP BY DaysToManufacture, StandardCost
    ORDER BY DaysToManufacture, StandardCost
) 'pvt|pivot([avg(StandardCost) as AverageCost],DaysToManufacture,[0,1,2,3,4])'

The PIVOT hint has the following format: 'pvt|pivot([aggregate_function(column) as alias], pivot_column, [pivot_values])'

  • aggregate_function(column) as alias: Specifies the aggregation to be performed and the alias for the result.
  • pivot_column: The column whose values will become new columns.
  • pivot_values: An array of values from the pivot column that will become new columns.

docs.title: UNPIVOT
docs.text:
The UNPIVOT operation is the reverse of PIVOT. It transforms columns into rows, converting a cross-tabular format back into a normalized form. In NoQL, the UNPIVOT operation is also specified as a hint on the subquery.

Example UNPIVOT usage 
SELECT VendorID, Employee, Orders
FROM (
    SELECT VendorID, Emp1, Emp2, Emp3, Emp4, Emp5, unset(_id)
    FROM pvt
) 'unpvt|unpivot(Orders,Employee,[Emp1, Emp2, Emp3, Emp4, Emp5])'
ORDER BY VendorID, Employee

The UNPIVOT hint has the following format: 'unpvt|unpivot(value_column, name_column, [column_list])'

  • value_column: The name of the new column that will contain the unpivoted values.
  • name_column: The name of the new column that will contain the names of the original columns.
  • column_list: An array of column names to be unpivoted.

Multiple UNPIVOT operations can be chained using the pipe (|) character:

Example of multiple UNPIVOT operations 
SELECT SalesID,
ROW_NUMBER() OVER (
        ORDER BY OrderName
    ) OrderNum,
OrderName,
OrderDate,
OrderAmt
FROM (
    SELECT SalesID, Order1Name, Order2Name, Order1Date, Order2Date, Order1Amt, Order2Amt, unset(_id)
    FROM multiple-unpivot
) 'unpvt|unpivot(OrderName,OrderNames,[Order1Name, Order2Name])|unpivot(OrderDate,OrderDates,[Order1Date, Order2Date])|unpivot(OrderAmt,OrderAmts,[Order1Amt, Order2Amt])'

Note: The exact capabilities and performance of PIVOT and UNPIVOT operations may depend on the specific implementation in NoQL and the underlying MongoDB version.

docs.title: Strings
docs.text:
Note

+ (str + str) does not work for string concatenation. Use CONCAT instead.

docs.title: LIKE
docs.text:
LIKE '%%'

Provides string match functionality with support for standard % notation. Case insensitive.

Example LIKE usage 
SELECT
    *
FROM
    `customers`
WHERE
  name LIKE 'john%';

docs.title: NOT LIKE
docs.text:
NOT LIKE '%%'

Provides string non match functionality with support for standard % notation. Case insensitive.

Example NOT LIKE usage 
SELECT
    *
FROM
    `customers`
WHERE
  name NOT LIKE 'john%';

docs.title: CONCAT
docs.text:
CONCAT(expr,expr,expr...)

Concatenates strings.

Example CONCAT usage 
SELECT
    CONCAT(`First Name`,‘:’,`Last Name`) AS exprVal
FROM
    `customers`;

docs.title: JOIN
docs.text:
JOIN(expr,separator)

Joins the field that is an array of strings using the separator string.

Example JOIN usage 
SELECT
    JOIN(`Addresses`,‘,’) AS fullAddress
FROM
    `customers`;

docs.title: TRIM
docs.text:
TRIM(expr,[chars])

Trims the string

Example TRIM usage 
SELECT
    TRIM(`First Name`,‘_ -‘) AS exprVal
FROM
    `customers`;

docs.title: LTRIM
docs.text:
LTRIM(expr,[chars])

Left trims the string

Example LTRIM usage 
SELECT
    LTRIM(`First Name`,‘_ -‘) AS exprVal
FROM
    `customers`;

docs.title: RTRIM
docs.text:
RTRIM(expr,[chars])

Right trims the string

Example RTRIM usage 
SELECT
    RTRIM(`First Name`,‘_ -‘) AS exprVal
FROM
    `customers`;

docs.title: SUBSTR
docs.text:
SUBSTR(expr,start,length)

Returns the substring of a string.

Example SUBSTR usage 
SELECT
    SUBSTR(`First Name`,1,10) AS exprVal
FROM
    `customers`;

docs.title: SUBSTR_BYTES
docs.text:
SUBSTR_BYTES(expr,start,length)

Returns the substring of a string by bytes.

Example SUBSTR_BYTES usage 
SELECT
    SUBSTR_BYTES(`First Name`,1,10) AS exprVal
FROM
    `customers`;

docs.title: REPLACE
docs.text:
REPLACE(expr,find,replace)

Replaces the first instance of a search string in an input string with a replacement string.

Example REPLACE usage 
SELECT
    REPLACE(`First Name`,‘a’,‘b’) AS exprVal
FROM
    `customers`;

docs.title: REPLACE_ALL
docs.text:
REPLACE_ALL(expr,find,replace)

Replaces all instances of a search string in an input string with a replacement string.

Example REPLACE_ALL usage 
SELECT
    REPLACE_ALL(`First Name`,‘a’,‘b’) AS exprVal
FROM
    `customers`;

docs.title: STRLEN
docs.text:
STRLEN(expr)

Returns the number of UTF-8 encoded bytes in the specified string.

Example STRLEN usage 
SELECT
    STRLEN(`First Name`)  AS exprVal
FROM
    `customers`;

docs.title: STRLEN_CP
docs.text:
STRLEN_CP(expr)

Returns the number of UTF-8 code points in the specified string.

Example STRLEN_CP usage 
SELECT
    STRLEN_CP(`First Name`)  AS exprVal
FROM
    `customers`;

docs.title: SPLIT
docs.text:
SPLIT(expr,delimiter)

Splits the string to an array.

Example SPLIT usage 
SELECT
    SPLIT(`First Name`,‘,’) AS exprVal
FROM
    `customers`;

docs.title: STRPOS
docs.text:
STRPOS(expr,substr)

Finds the first index of the substring within the expression. Returns 0 if not found and 1 based index position as per PostgresQL.

Example STRPOS usage 
SELECT
    STRPOS(Title,'B') as pos,filmId
FROM
    films
WHERE
    STRPOS(Title,'B') > 0;

docs.title: LOCATE
docs.text:
LOCATE(expr,substr)

Finds the first index of the substring within the expression. Returns 0 if not found and 1 based index position as per MySQL.

Example LOCATE usage 
SELECT
    LOCATE(Title,'B') as pos,filmId
FROM
    films
WHERE
    LOCATE(Title,'B') > 0;

docs.title: LEFT
docs.text:
LEFT(expr, length)

Returns the leftmost characters from the expression.

Example LEFT usage 
SELECT
    LEFT(`First Name`, 3) AS firstThreeChars
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: STARTS_WITH
docs.text:
STARTS_WITH(expr, prefix)

Returns true if the expression starts with the specified prefix.

Example STARTS_WITH usage 
SELECT
    id,
    `First Name`,
    STARTS_WITH(`First Name`, 'Jo') AS startsWithJo
FROM `customers`;

docs.title: WRAP_PARAM
docs.text:
WRAP_PARAM(expr, [forceString])

Wraps a parameter, typically used for handling special characters or ensuring correct interpretation of a string.

Example WRAP_PARAM usage 
SELECT
    WRAP_PARAM('Hello, "World"!') as wrappedString,
    WRAP_PARAM(42, true) as wrappedNumber
FROM
    `customers`
LIMIT 1

In this example, WRAP_PARAM ensures that the string with quotes is properly handled, and when forceString is set to true, it forces the number to be treated as a string.

docs.title: Union
docs.text:
NoQL supports UNION and UNION ALL.

Example UNION usage 
SELECT * FROM top_rated_films
UNION
SELECT * FROM most_popular_films;
Example UNION ALL usage 
SELECT * FROM top_rated_films
UNION ALL
SELECT * FROM most_popular_films;

Unions can be used in sub queries.

docs.title: WHERE Clauses
docs.text:
WHERE clauses are used to filter the results of a query. They are used in the same way as in SQL.

Functions in WHERE clauses require explicit definition and can't use a computed field

Correct function and WHERE clause usage 
--Correct
SELECT 
    `Address.City` AS City
    ,ABS(`id`) AS absId 
FROM 
    `customers` 
WHERE 
    `First Name` LIKE 'm%' AND ABS(`id`) > 1 
ORDER BY 
    absId
Incorrect function and WHERE clause usage 
--Won't work
SELECT 
    `Address.City` AS City
    ,ABS(`id`) AS absId 
FROM 
    `customers` 
WHERE 
    `First Name` LIKE 'm%' AND absId > 1

docs.title: Selecting on a calculated column by name
docs.text:
Calculated columns in WHERE clauses can only be used with aggregates

Calculated columns in WHERE clauses with aggregates 
--have to repeat select statement as with sql rules
SELECT 
    id
    ,Title
    ,Rating
    ,ABS(id) AS absId 
FROM 
    `films` 
WHERE ABS(id)=1

docs.title: Window Functions
docs.text: Window functions applies aggregate and ranking functions over a particular window (set of rows).

docs.title: RANK
docs.text:
The RANK() function assigns a rank to every row within a partition of a result set.

For each partition, the rank of the first row is 1. The RANK() function adds the number of tied rows to the tied rank to calculate the rank of the next row, so the ranks may not be sequential. In addition, rows with the same values will get the same rank.

Correct RANK usage 
--Correct
SELECT  value,
        RANK () OVER (
            ORDER BY value
        ) rank_number,
        unset(_id)
FROM function-test-data
WHERE testId='bugfix.rank.case1'

docs.title: ROW_NUMBER
docs.text:
The ROW_NUMBER() function is a window function that assigns a sequential integer to each row in a result set.

Correct ROW_NUMBER usage 
--Correct
SELECT  value,
        ROW_NUMBER() OVER (
            ORDER BY value
        ) row_number,
        unset(_id)
FROM function-test-data
WHERE testId='bugfix.rank.case1'

docs.title: DENSE_RANK
docs.text:
The DENSE_RANK() assigns a rank to every row in each partition of a result set. Different from the RANK() function, the DENSE_RANK() function always returns consecutive rank values.

For each partition, the DENSE_RANK() function returns the same rank for the rows which have the same values

Correct DENSE_RANK usage 
--Correct
SELECT  value,
        DENSE_RANK () OVER (
            ORDER BY value
        ) rank_number,
        unset(_id)
FROM function-test-data
WHERE testId='bugfix.dense-rank.case1'
